Topic: Draw a habitat and the different living things in each
CAN: The student can draw a basic outline of a land-based habitat, such as a simple representation of a garden or forest.
The student can include a few different kinds of living things, like trees and a couple of obvious animals such as a squirrel and maybe a bird or an ant.
The student can show simple patterns by including more than one of a single type of plant or animal (such as multiple trees).
CANNOT: The student may not accurately represent more complex habitats like a pond, stream, or lake with specific aquatic plants or animals *(student may not understand aquatic environments)*.
The student may struggle to organize the drawing clearly to identify and label distinct habitats and living things within each one *(mixing elements between land and water habitats)*.
The student might try to include different habitats but does so inconsistently and without clear comparisons in diversity *(elements might be randomly scattered without context)*.
The student may label some elements incorrectly or not at all due to emerging understanding *(inconsistent or incorrect identification of species)*.
